code: @Manual{,   title = {windscape: Landscape connectivity by wind},   author = {Matthew Kling},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://matthewkling.github.io/windscape/}, }

title: Landscape connectivity by wind
text: windscape R package models landscape connectivity wind dispersal. prior wind connectivity models like rWind package support connectivity modeling based snapshot wind conditions, windscape designed model integrate short-term long-term time series wind conditions across landscape, estimating windborne diffusion across scales ranging days millennia. models estimate directional wind travel times pair sites, can therefore used generate upwind immigration downwind emigration accessibility surfaces focal site example . early version package, ongoing development. core functionality stable, documentation incomplete, additional features planned, future API changes possible.

title: Landscape connectivity by wind
text: devtools::install_github("matthewkling/windscape")

title: Landscape connectivity by wind
text: core workflow currently supported package begins raster stack representing time series windfields, summarizes set time-integrated wind conductance values every grid cell eight neighbors, converts asymmetric transition object (defined gdistance package) representing either upwind downwind connectivity. example code shows workflow models visualizes upwind downwind accessibility focal site North America, based wind data days year 2000. second example demonstrates calculate pairwise wind flows among set sites, run Mantel tests relationships wind flow ecological data. detailed set vignettes development.  example, used wind connectivity model estimate wind flows one site locations across region. alternative use case instead estimate pairwise wind connecitivity among set sites (e.g. locations populations landscape genetic data sampled). example shows using downwind connectivity model set site coordinates. also demonstrates run statistical hypothesis tests wind flow, wind speed, wind asymmetry relate hypothetical genetic data set (see details hypotheses). genetic data generated randomly example, results significant.
code: library(windscape) library(raster) library(tidyverse) library(gdistance)  # Download some hourly wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis. # We'll grab data for a chunk of North America for 24 days distributed across a single year, # though a proper study would want to use a denser sampling of data wind <- cfsr_dl(years = 2000, months = 1:12, days = c(1, 15),                 xlim = c(-120, -90) + 360, # shift longitudes to be in [0, 360] range for CFSR                 ylim = c(30, 50))  # convert to raster::stack and shift longitude to the standard [-180, 180] range wind <- shift(stack(wind), dx = -360)  # summarize wind time series (n = 1152 hourly layers) into  # a wind conductance or "windrose" raster (n = 8 directional layers) conductance <- windrose_rasters(wind, order = "uuvv", p = 1)  # convert raster data into upwind and downwind connectivity graphs downwind <- build_wind_graph(conductance, "downwind") upwind <- build_wind_graph(conductance, "upwind")  # generate upwind and downwind dispersal surfaces for one focal site  site <- matrix(c(-105, 40), ncol = 2) downwind_hrs <-  accCost(downwind, site) upwind_hrs <-  accCost(upwind, site)  # restructure data and plot d <- stack(downwind_hrs, upwind_hrs) %>%       rasterToPoints() %>%       as.data.frame() %>%       gather(direction, wind_hours, layer.1, layer.2) %>%       mutate(direction = recode(direction,                                  layer.1 = "downwind (outbound)",                                  layer.2 = "upwind (inbound)")) ggplot(d) +       facet_wrap(~direction) +       geom_raster(aes(x, y, fill = wind_hours)) +       geom_contour(aes(x, y, z = wind_hours), bins = 20, color = "white", linewidth = .25) +       geom_point(data = as.data.frame(site), aes(V1, V2)) +       coord_fixed(ratio = 1.2) +       scale_fill_gradientn(colors=c("yellow", "red", "blue", "black")) +       theme_void() +       theme(legend.position="top",             strip.text=element_text(size=15)) # lon-lat coordinates for a set of focal sites sites <- cbind(x = runif(20, -115, -95),                y = runif(20, 33, 47))  # pairwise wind flows among sites (notice that this is an asymmetric matrix) wind_flow <- gdistance::costDistance(downwind, sites)  # pairwise geographic distance between sites (symmetric, converted to km) # (for use as a control variable in the partial Mantel tests) distance <- geosphere::distm(sites) / 1000   # test correlation between wind flow and gene flow, controlling for distance gene_flow <- matrix(runif(400), 20) # simulate random gene flow data r <- mantel_test(wind_flow, gene_flow, z = list(distance))  # test correlation between bidirectional wind connectivity and genetic isolation, # controlling for distance gene_dist <- matrix(runif(400), 20) # simulate random gene flow data wind_conn <- pairwise_means(wind_flow) # convert to symmetric matrix r <- mantel_test(wind_conn, gene_dist, z = list(distance))  # test correlation between wind asymmetry and gene flow asymmetry # (no distance control is needed for a test of reciprocally symmetric matrices) wind_asym <- pairwise_ratios(wind_flow) # convert to asymmetry matrix gene_asym <- pairwise_ratios(gene_flow) # convert to asymmetry matrix r <- mantel_test(wind_asym, gene_asym)  # test correlation between wind asymmetry and genetic diversity asymmetry diversity <- runif(20) # simulated diversity for each population div_asym <- pairwise_ratios(diversity) # pairwise diversity ratios r <- mantel_test(wind_asym, div_asym)

title: Landscape connectivity by wind
text: R package powers WINDSCAPE WEB APP (still development beta) models visualizes wind dispersal landscape location earth. just click map select site, choose “inbound” (upwind) “outbound” (downwind) dispersal, app generates global map relative accessibility wind. app utilizes decades hourly wind data Climate Forecast System Renanalysis estimate long-term average wind travel times locations.

title: Landscape connectivity by wind
text: Publications used windscape framework include: Kling, M., D. Ackerly. (2021) Global wind patterns shape genetic differentiation, asymmetric gene flow, genetic diversity trees. Proceedings National Academy Sciences, 118(17) [https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2017317118] Kling, M., D. Ackerly. (2020) Global wind patterns vulnerability wind-dispersed species climate change. Nature Climate Change, 10: 868-875 [https://doi.org/10.1038/s41558-020-0848-3]

what: Download wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) — cfsr_dl
title: Download wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) — cfsr_dl
text: function downloads hourly CFSR wind data NCAR THREDDS server, one historic dates, within spatial bounding box. Data factorial combinations 'years', 'months', 'days' downloaded combined.

title: Download wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) — cfsr_dl
code: cfsr_dl(   years = 1979,   months = 1,   days = 1,   xlim = c(260, 270),   ylim = c(40, 50) )

title: Download wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) — cfsr_dl
text: years Integer vector representing historic year(s) data accessed, range 1979-2010. months Integer vector representing month(s) data accessed, range 1-12. days Integer vector representing day(s) data requested, range 0-31. xlim Vector length 2, giving longitudinal limits data download, range 0 360. ylim Vector length 2, giving latitudinal limits data download, range -90 90.

title: Download wind data from the Climate Forecast System Reanalysis (CFSR) — cfsr_dl
text: list containing u v components wind field, SpatRaster layer hour requested date.

title: Mantel test — mantel_test
text: version Mantel test supports asymmetric matrices multiple partial-Mantel controls, combination features possible using widely available Mantel functions mantel.partial.

title: Mantel test — mantel_test
code: mantel_test(   x,   y,   z = NULL,   nperm = 999,   method = "pearson",   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater") )

title: Mantel test — mantel_test
text: x, y Square matrices (can asymmetric). z Optional list one square control matrices partial Mantel desired. nperm Number random permutations perform (positive integer). method Correlation method (see cor details). alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less".

title: Mantel test — mantel_test
text: list following components: `stat`: correlation coefficient x y, measured data provided. partial correlation z specified. `quantile`: quantile observed stat null distribution. `p.value`: Significance, derived combination quantile alternative. `perm`: vector null correlations based permuted data.

title: Mantel test — mantel_test

what: Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
title: Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
text: function produces symmetrical matrix values representing pairwise means directional flows asymmetric put matrix. output can used tests strength direction-agnostic connectivity among nodes data set (e.g. "isolation" hypothesis; Kling Ackerly (2021)).

title: Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
text: x square matrix entries representing directional edge weights pairs nodes.

title: Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
text: symmetrical square matrix size x, values representing pairwise means directional flows x.

title: Convert asymmetric pairwise matrix to symmetrical matrix of pairwise means — pairwise_means
text: Kling Ackerly (2021). Global wind patterns shape genetic differentiation, asymmetric gene flow, genetic diversity trees. Proceedings National Academy Sciences. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2017317118

what: Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
title: Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
text: function produces "pairwise ratio matrix" can used tests asymmetric flows among nodes data set (e.g. "asymmetry" "diversity" hypotheses; Kling Ackerly (2021)). input data set can asymmetric matrix entries representing directed edge weights (e.g. directional flows wind genes connecting pair populations "nodes"), can vector node attributes (e.g. properties site population, genetic diversity).

title: Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
text: x Either square matrix entries representing directional edge weights pairs nodes, numeric vector value node. log ratios log-transformed? Default TRUE, since generates symmetrical frequency distribution desirable analyses.

title: Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
text: square matrix size x, ones diagonal reciprocal values upper lower triangles. x matrix, output represents ratios -diagonal -diagonal values x. x vector, output represents ratios every pairwise combination x values; e.g. matrix value cell [2,4] equals x[2] / x[4].

title: Convert data to reciprocally symmetrical pairwise matrix — pairwise_ratios
text: Kling Ackerly (2021). Global wind patterns shape genetic differentiation, asymmetric gene flow, genetic diversity trees. Proceedings National Academy Sciences. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2017317118

title: Simulate wind diffusion — random_walk
text: function estimates diffusion across windscape Markov random walk. iteration, "particle mass" grid cell dispersed within local 9-cell neighborhood proportion wind conductance. Depending usage, "mass" represent probability, number individuals, etc. simulation proceeds, mass diffuses across landscape.

title: Simulate wind diffusion — random_walk
code: random_walk(x, init, iter = 100, record = iter, ratchet = FALSE)

title: Simulate wind diffusion — random_walk
text: x `wind_rose`. init Initial conditions begin diffusion, either two-column matrix coordinates, SpatRaster layer non-negative mass values spatial properties `x`. coordinates, simulation starts mass 1 coordinate location. SpatRaster, diffusion done directly raster; result prior random_walk, data representing quantities spatially dispersed. iter Number simulation iterations (positive integer). record Integer vector specifying iterations record. Default record final iteration, .e. `iter`. One raster layer returned value `record`. ratchet Whether "ratchet " values diffusion. Default FALSE. See details.

title: Simulate wind diffusion — random_walk
text: input wind rose raster converted simplex nine probabilities grid cell, giving rates particles retained cell moved eight neighbors. Probabilities moving neighboring cell proportional conductance wind rose data set, probabilities remaining cell scaled cell highest conductance zero retention probability; allows conductance normalized locally simplex remaining proportional across cells maximizing dispersal occurring iteration. default, simulation tracks fleeting diffusion initial "pulse" particle mass, drift spread like cloud, eventually leaving modeling domain (unless closed spatial domain). alternative setting `ratchet = TRUE` instead runs propagating simulation local particle mass never declines, continuing transmit mass cumulative maximum rate; may akin biological process particles can reproduce locally establishment.

what: Calculate 8-neighbor edge loadings from a time series of u and v windspeeds — rose
title: Calculate 8-neighbor edge loadings from a time series of u and v windspeeds — rose

Calculate 8-neighbor edge loadings from a time series of u and v windspeeds — rose
text: x vector wind data containing: latitude, resolution, u windspeeds, v windspeeds p positive number indicating power raise windspeeds (see details)

title: Calculate 8-neighbor edge loadings from a time series of u and v windspeeds — rose
text: vector 8 conductance values neighboring cells, clockwise   starting southwest neighbor. input windspeeds m/s,   values (1 / hours ^ p)

title: Calculate 8-neighbor edge loadings from a time series of u and v windspeeds — rose
text: value p = 0 ignore speed, assigning weights based   direction . P = 1 assumes conductance proportional windspeed, p =   2 assumes proportional aerodynamic drag, p = 3 assumes   proportional force. intermediate value can also used.

what: Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
title: Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
text: function creates `wind_rose` object summarizing distribution wind speed direction observations grid cell. result set eight raster layers giving average wind conductance toward cell's 'queen' neighbors.

title: Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
text: x Data set class `wind_field`. trans Either function, positive number indicating power raise windspeeds ; see details. ... Additional arguments passed `terra::app`, e.g. 'filename'.

title: Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
text: 8-layer raster stack, layer wind conductance   focal cell one neighbors (clockwise starting SW).   input windspeeds m/s `trans = 1`, values (1 / hours)

title: Summarize a set of wind_field rasters into a wind_rose object — wind_rose
text: `trans` parameter defines transformation function used convert wind speed conductance. numeric value supplied, function speed^trans used. value trans = 0 ignore speed, assigning weights based direction ; trans = 1 assumes conductance proportional windspeed, trans = 2 assumes proportional aerodynamic drag, trans = 3 assumes proportional force. intermediate value can also used. function transforms numeric vector can also supplied; example, model seed dispersal species releases seeds winds exceed 10 m/s, specify threshold function `trans = function(x)x[x < 10] <- 0; return(x)`.

text: x used internally within `transition_stack`, vector collated windrose values cells direction either "downwind" (default) "upwind", indicating whether outbound inbound wind conductance computed.
